thread.title: Tax changes may feature in budget: PM
thread.title_full: Tax changes may feature in budget: PM | Business Spectator

author: AAP
title: Tax changes may feature in budget: PM
text:
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull says there could be tax changes in the the May budget, but any major reforms will be taken to the next federal election.
Mr Turnbull said federal taxes already were a high percentage of GDP and the government did want to increase that level of taxation.
"We will certainly be taking decisions in the lead-up to the budget and obviously if we have major tax reforms we will take them to the next election," he told 3AW Radio on Tuesday.
The prime minister then dismissed the findings of a new report that warns the China free trade deal will invite a wave of Chinese workers.
The report, commissioned by the Electrical Trades Union, claims the deal will allow the government to surrender autonomy over its migration laws.
"The dire forecasts that some of the unions have been putting out there are grossly misleading," Mr Turnbull told Melbourne radio 3AW.
Mr Tunbull also confirmed he was sounded out for the job of Australian ambassador to the US but declined because it wasn't "his cup of tea".
Mr Turnbull's name was in the mix as the Abbott government earlier in the year considered a replacement for former Labor leader Kim Beazley who is due to leave the Washington post at the end of the year.
"I cannot imagine circumstances where I would want to be an ambassador," the prime minister told 3AW.
